title: Oil Circuit - Description

body.body: The two crankcase halves create two separate chambers for the crankshaft and the transmission. The lubricating oil collects in the bottom of the transmission chamber. Oil from the transmission chamber is drawn through the oil strainer into a gallery in the right crankcase half.

The oil then passes back through the central crankcase dowel into the oil pump, which is located in the left crankcase half. The oil pump is of an internal rotor type and is gear driven from the crankshaft. The pump body has an integral pressure relief valve to release excess oil pressure.

Pressurised oil exits the pump into a gallery that leads to the oil filter. Oil passes through the outside of the oil filter to the inside and exits the centre of the filter into a chamber between the crankcase halves.

The pressurised oil in the chamber exits through apertures in the left and right sides into galleries drilled in each crankcase half. These galleries supply oil to the balancer shaft bearings, crankshaft main bearings, piston cooling jets and gearbox output shaft bearings.

The gallery in the left crankcase also supplies oil to two pipes called oil rails. One oil rail extends across the top of the clutch assembly to lubricate the clutch. The second oil rail extends across the top of the gear clusters and gear change mechanism to lubricate the transmission components.

Oil from the left main bearing passes through drillings in the crankshaft to lubricate the big end bearing. The piston pin bearings are lubricated by the piston cooling jets that spray oil under the piston as it rises and falls during engine operation.
The oil sprayed under the piston carries excess heat away from the piston skirt. Drillings in the piston allow oil to pass through the skirt to lubricate the cylinder bore.
Oil from the left crankcase gallery also passes around the left, rear cylinder head bolt, upwards through the cylinder and into the cylinder head.

Drillings in the cylinder head transfer oil to the oil pressure switch and channels in the camshaft ladder. The channels distribute oil around the cylinder head to lubricate the camshaft bearings, camshaft lobes and cam followers through spray jets.

Oil from the camshaft bearings, lobes and followers returns through an aperture in the cylinder head into the camshaft drive chain tunnel to lubricate the chain. An aperture in the bottom of the left crankcase allows the drained oil to return into the transmission chamber.

Openings in the right crankcase allow oil to pass through from the crankshaft chamber into the right outer chamber that houses the alternator and starter drive. As the alternator rotor turns, it throws up oil and lubricates the starter drive gears and bearings by spray distribution.
Oil that collects in the crankshaft chamber is drawn through the evacuation strainer by the evacuation oil pump. The evacuation oil pump returns the oil to the transmission chamber.
The evacuation oil pump is driven by the same drive shaft as the main oil pump.
